DAZ Studio Plug-in Activation and Serialization

3rd party developers can use the DZ_PLUGIN_ACTIVATION_POLICY() macro and DzActivationPolicy classes in their plug-in definition to provide evaluation periods. The current evaluation periods that are implemented are a fixed expiration date and a limited day trial (from the first day the plug-in is loaded).

The syntax for DZ_PLUGIN_ACTIVATION_POLICY() is:

    DZ_PLUGIN_ACTIVATION_POLICY( <plugin guid>, <activation policy> )

The plug-in guid is a unique guid for the plug-in, just like those generated for the classes that are registered with the class factory. It should be generated in the same manner.

The activation policy is a pointer to the desired activation policy to be used by the plug-in for evaluation period.

The DZ_PLUGIN_REGISTRATION_PREFIX() macro is used to designate serial number prefixes and their description to be assocated with the plug-in for activating its functionality with a serial number entered by the user.

The syntax for DZ_PLUGIN_REGISTRATION_PREFIX() is:

    DZ_PLUGIN_REGISTRATION_PREFIX( <serial prefix>, <version string>, <prefix description> )

The serial prefix argument is the serial number prefix assigned to you by DAZ 3D, if you choose to use our serial number registration support. To request a serial number prefix you should email dazserialprefix@daz3d.com with the following information:

  • DAZ 3D store username
  • Plug-in name
  • Plug-in version number

The version string argument is a string representation of the serialization version, which will be provided to you by DAZ 3D when you request a serial number prefix.

The prefix description is the user readable string description of the serial number prefix.

Here are a few examples:

This is a simple sample plug-in that is always activated. It's not necessary to include this, as it is the default behavior of plug-ins that do not specify an activation policy, but is included for completeness's sake:

    DZ_PLUGIN_ACTIVATION_POLICY( xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx, new DzActivationPolicy() );

This is a sample plug-in that is purely a 60 day evaluation copy and cannot be unlocked for long term usage. The same can be done with an expiration date:

    DZ_PLUGIN_ACTIVATION_POLICY( xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx, new DzTrialDaysActivationPolicy(60) );

This sample is a plug-in that can be activated with a serial number. It also has an 30 day trial evaluation period:

    DZ_PLUGIN_ACTIVATION_POLICY( xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx, new DzTrialDaysActivationPolicy(30) );
    DZ_PLUGIN_REGISTRATION_PREFIX( SDKSMPL, "010", "SDK Sample" );

This sample is a plug-in that belongs to a bundle and as such can be activated with multiple serial numbers. It also has an expiration date evaluation period:

    DZ_PLUGIN_ACTIVATION_POLICY( xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx, new DzExpirationDateActivationPolicy(2010,3,24) );
    DZ_PLUGIN_REGISTRATION_PREFIX( SDKSMPL, "010", "SDK Sample" );
    DZ_PLUGIN_REGISTRATION_PREFIX( SDKSPBN, "010", "SDK Megapack" );

This sample is a plug-in that belongs to a bundle and can only be activated with a serial number. The user will not be able to evaluate the plug-in functionality before registering.

    DZ_PLUGIN_ACTIVATION_POLICY( xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx, new DzNoEvaluationActivationPolicy() );
    DZ_PLUGIN_REGISTRATION_PREFIX( SDKSMPL, "010", "SDK Sample" );
    DZ_PLUGIN_REGISTRATION_PREFIX( SDKSPBN, "010", "SDK Megapack" );

As shown the first sample, if you do not wish to utilize the serial number or activation policy functionality, it is not necessary to use the DZ_PLUGIN_ACTIVATION_POLICY() or DZ_PLUGIN_REGISTRATION_PREFIX() macros in your plug-in definition at all.

It's also possible for 3rd party developers to sub-class DzActivationPolicy to implement their own policies. The activated(), initialized(), and usesRegistration() functions should be reimplemented to match the behavior of the derived activation policy.
